- Conduct and publish 2016 edition of Strategic Conflict Assessment and report. - Two communities with existence of peace building infrastructure. - Conduct refresher course for 200 Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps (NSCDC) Peace Officers on alternative dispute resolution (ADR) and share experience on best practice. - Train strategic level officers across all security agencies in Nigeria on intelligence sharing, effective co-ordination and crisis management. - Validate the report of socio-economic and infrastructure resource database in the Niger Delta. - Design and install monitoring and evaluation system to track Niger Delta development in the Ministry of Niger Delta Affairs (MNDA). - Place 495 victims of insurgency in the North East in technical and vocational skill centres for 6 months to one year programme.

- 2016 edition of Strategic Conflict Assessment draft report ready. - 15 communities in 5 states have functional community peace building infrastructure. - 230 NSCDC Peace Officers retrained on alternative dispute resolution (ADR) and shared experiences on best practice. A remarkable 12,134 civil cases resolved by the officers in 2016. - 351 strategic level security officers across all security agencies in Nigeria trained on intelligence sharing, effective co-ordination and crisis management. - The report of socio-economic and infrastructure resource database in the Niger Delta validated. - Web-based monitoring and evaluation system to track Niger Delta development designed, installed and functional in MNDA. - 258 of the 495 reoriented women and youths, victims of insurgency in the North East, placed in a technical and a vocational skill acquisition centre for 6 months (179) and one year (79) period respectively.

1. The communication plan developed in 2015 was reviewed during the 2nd National Technical Committee Meeting, held on 10th March 2016. The meeting recommended the active inclusion of Civil Society Organizations to work with office of National Security voluntarily in the field. 2. Live interactive radio programmes were conducted on selected radio stations with wider coverage like eastern FM Radio Station to sensitize the populace on the dangers associated with SALW. 3. Jingles were developed and aired in four national languages. Radio sensitization covered over 90% of the populace and was conducted at the District headquarter towns of Kono, Kailahun, Kenema and Koinadugu. 4. Sexual and Gender Based Violence training was conducted in four Districts namely Kono, Kenema, Kailahun and Koinadugu targeting a total of 80 participants of which 20 were women. Which has resulted in increased knowledge and awareness and also a reduction in cases of SGBV. 5. Four (4) 20ft. containers procured in 2015 were partitioned and transported to the Police Security posts in Kenema, Kailahun, Kono and Koinadugu in line with ISACS standards.

1. Information, Education and Communication materials based on experiences from year one and two for dissemination. 2. Organize a review of the training provided to stakeholders to assess results. 3. Organize one end of project knowledge/ experience sharing workshop for NATCOMS and key stakeholders. 4. Conduct destruction of recovered weapons from communities 5. Update records of all arms collected over the project period. 6. Conduct project evaluation

1. Radio discussion programmes in line with the communications strategy; jingles aired in four main local languages; Community sensitization programmes; Needs Assessment Community Action Planning were conducted. This has raised both community and national awareness of the humanitarian impact and wider socio economic and development costs of small arms problems which has led to the voluntary surrender of SALW in these communities. 2. Training on Resource Mobilisation for NATCOM personnel's using the ‘Result Chain Thinking’ training method was successfully conducted with 16 men and 4 women. This has added new skills for them to better manage resources. Also the National Technical Committee meeting was held wherein members reviewed activities and to facilitate national ownership of the project. 3. Weapons collection have been conducted in two Districts (71 local guns and 30 UXOs) which have been stored in project storage facilities and UXOs diffused by NATCOM using local materials. 4. Six (6) Hand Pump Wells implemented in the two chiefdoms as part of the community projects for arms recovered. This has encourage other community members who have now expressed their desire to surrender weapons/ammunition voluntarily in the coming year.

1. Successfuly conducted critical border assesment in five (5) new Counties of the Country, as a result all the 5 Counties are ready for the implementation on the follow up project. 2.16 CSOs were trained on community engagemet for security and development of which 8 were women. As a result, the trainees contributed to the engagement and re-engagement of the communities in their respective Counties. 3. The ECOWAS EU Small Arms Project Communication Strategy developed in 2015 was updated to include educational manuals, town criers with over 1000 Educational manuals for border community schools were produced; 15 town criers were engaged to disseminate information in local languages in targeted regions. 2. In Danane, Gbon-Houye, Glan-Houye, and Toulepleu Pehe and Tiobli in total, 71 war arms, 6996 ammunitions, 6 Grenades and 4 Rockets were collected during this exercise. comment.narrative: Most of the local businesses have been burnt or destroyed and agriculture sector stagnates. Access to basic socio-economic services is disrupted for IDPs and over stretched for host communities. Increased acts of violence, human rights abuses and gender based violence. -Training conducted for first batch of 2,000 Community-Based Vigilantes and CJTF members. This will enable them contribute to cross-border community security, early warning and early response in LCB region.

description.narrative: The programme aims to stabilize local communities devastated by Boko Haram in North East Region of Nigeria through integrated approach focusing on the four inter-related areas: livelihoods, social cohesion, basic services, and local governance.
